channel.description: The top News headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit https://www.smh.com.au
channel.title: Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News

item.description: Iran, Israel’s arch-enemy in the Middle East, has been a key supporter, along with Russia, of President Bashar al-Assad during Syria's civil war.
item.title: Israel's outgoing defence minister says Iran starting to withdraw from Syria

item.dc:creator: Matt Bungard
item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: Coronavirus updates LIVE: Australian push for COVID-19 inquiry considered at World Health Assembly as global cases surpass 4.7 million, nation's death toll stands at 99

item.description: Wall Street soared to a 10-week high and the ASX is set for big gains this morning on encouraging early-stage data for a potential coronavirus vaccine and on the promise of more stimulus to lift the US economy.
item.title: Wall Street surges, ASX to jump on vaccine hopes and stimulus promise

item.description: The global economy will take much longer to recover fully from the shock caused by the new coronavirus than initially expected.
item.title: IMF chief warns full global economic recovery 'will take much longer' than first thought

item.dc:creator: Anthony Galloway
item.description: A global inquiry into the coronavirus will be established on Tuesday.
item.title: Global inquiry into coronavirus will pass, China and US being urged to sign on

item.dc:creator: Bevan Shields
item.description: The European Union would be allowed to raise joint debt under an unprecedented coronavirus recovery plan.
item.title: Merkel and Macron find new and 'unnatural path' to stave off trouble in Europe

item.description: US President Donald Trump has repeatedly said, without evidence, that the Obama administration acted corruptly.
item.title: 'No criminal probe': Barr pours cold water on Trump's Obama allegations

item.description: The company's chief executive officer has announced Uber's second round of job cuts during the coronavirus pandemic.
item.title: Uber goes back to basics as it cuts a further 3000 jobs

item.dc:creator: Fergus Hunter
item.description: The snap review found pockets of dissatisfaction with the package and said it will need to adapt as the economy opens up.
item.title: Review of childcare rescue package finds it saved the sector but needs to adapt

item.description: The best photos from the international wire agencies as chosen by our picture editors.
item.title: Gallery: The best photos from around the world

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, May 19, 2020

item.dc:creator: Carrie Fellner
item.description: Apartment buyers who remain locked out of an Erskineville development two years after it was completed would finally be allowed into their homes.
item.title: 'What sane person would wait five years?': Hope for unit owners after toxin delay

item.description: Follow our rolling coverage.
item.title: Tablet interactive: Coronavirus outbreak

item.dc:creator: Angus Thompson
item.description: A major urban think tank is backing calls for a lane of the Sydney Harbour Bridge to be set aside for cyclists.
item.title: 'Huge statement': cycling group wants Harbour Bridge lane for commute

item.dc:creator: Chris Roots
item.description: Micro-ownership company will give the public the opportunity to part-own a slot in Australia's richest race after buying the GPI Racing slot for the 2020 edition.
item.title: 'It's everyone’s dream now': Punters get chance to own an Everest slot

item.dc:creator: Matt O'Sullivan
item.description: The city has lost momentum in some sectors due to the coronavirus crisis, but is making up ground in others, the Greater Sydney Commission says.
item.title: Sydney attractive to advanced manufacturing as other sectors slump

item.dc:creator: Nick Miller
item.description: A classical music patron has thrown his support behind a season of online concerts, giving struggling musicians work and an income.
item.title: Lifeline for classical musicians as donor steps forward

item.dc:creator: Peter Hartcher
item.description: Australia's greatest ally is proving unreliable and not even especially capable.
item.title: On the brink of peril, Australia is left wondering what the mad sheriff has in mind

item.dc:creator: Alexandra Smith
item.description: While face-to-face teaching will resume after weeks of remote lessons, school will not return to normal, with no assemblies, no inter-school sport, and parents to be kept off campus to reduce the risk of COVID-19.
item.title: Berejiklian sends NSW students back to school full-time from May 25

item.dc:creator: Mike Foley
item.description: The Morrison government is considering legislative changes to allow its clean energy agencies to fund carbon capture and storage from fossil fuel projects in a bid to unlock $2 billion of private investment to reduce greenhouse gases.
item.title: Government looks to carbon capture for climate action

item.dc:creator: Tom Rabe
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Sydneysiders will be restricted from travelling into the CBD under new public transport measures.
item.title: Sydney bus drivers told not to enforce strict new COVID-19 measures

item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Knight
item.description: The iron ore price surge makes Virgin small change for Fortescue's $15 billion man.
item.title: Money and a mascot: What Forrest offers a Virgin bidding syndicate

item.dc:creator: Jenna Price
item.description: Colleges provide settings which make it possible for some to believe there are no rules.
item.title: At Sydney uni's privilege factories the 'mostly migrant' workers clean up rich kids' mess

item.dc:creator: Broede Carmody
item.description: Now is the perfect time to catch up on the best books, films, television shows, music and podcasts you might have missed.
item.title: Five multiplayer video games that put the social in social distancing

item.description: We went from living apart on weekdays to being together 24/7 and it's deepened our bond.
item.title: Lockdown is as lovely as it is lonely when you're in a new relationship

item.dc:creator: Broede Carmody
item.description: Claire Lyon says it is an incredible privilege to continue working in South Korea given the pandemic has decimated musicals worldwide.
item.title: Australian stars in major production staged during COVID-19

item.description: The best way to get growth back into the economy is through improving workforce participation.
item.title: Replace free childcare scheme with tax deductions to kickstart economy

item.dc:creator: Timna Jacks
item.description: Runaway growth on Melbourne's fringe creates a need for greater housing density. For some, that could mean giving up on a free-standing house, car park and backyard.
item.title: 'How do you do density?' Infrastructure Victoria asks residents

item.dc:creator: Harriet Alexander
item.description: Water Minister Melinda Pavey is about to sign off on latest water-sharing plans, but they neglect to take the two most recent droughts into account.
item.title: Latest drought data not used in new water plans

item.description: COVID-19 likes close and prolonged contact and that is just what public transport often provides.
item.title: Shame about the cars, but Premier is right to be cautious about public transport

item.description: The lockdown experience has helped us triage our preoccupations, and should make it easier to shed a few bad habits.
item.title: A post-pandemic reset: work smarter, be kinder

item.description: The latest lifestyle trend sees city slickers fantasising about a simpler life in the country. Optional extras: gingham, an organic veggie patch and baby lambs.
item.title: 'Cottagecore' has the young, urban crowd craving country life

item.dc:creator: Harry Hollinsworth
item.description: Mrs Mary Tenison Woods of Sydney has been appointed to the Human Rights Division of the United Nations.
item.title: In the Herald: May 19, 1950

item.dc:creator: Carrie Fellner
item.description: He was a man who “cared about everyone except himself”. But when it was his turn to be looked after, the hospital system let him down, says his family.
item.title: No food or Panadol: anger over 'third world' conditions before hospital death

item.description: 70 years ago, Prime Minister Robert Menzies announced that Australia would aid the United Kingdom in its fight against "imperialistic Communist aggression" in (then) Malaya.
item.title: From the Archives, 1950: Australia commits to the Malayan Emergency

item.description: Trivia buffs: test your knowledge with today's interactive superquiz and target.
item.title: Target and superquiz, Tuesday, May 19

item.dc:creator: Kylar Loussikian
item.description: Will the ascension of Magellan director Hamish McLennan to the chairmanship of Rugby Australia make it easier for the embattled code to land a lucrative broadcast deal with Fox Sports?
item.title: Rugby boss's News Corp history means little in hopes for Foxtel deal

item.dc:creator: Jewel Topsfield
item.description: A $100 million fund to promote recycling had invested no money into manufacturing projects by late March.
item.title: Morrison's $100m recycling fund yet to invest in projects

item.dc:creator: Linda Morris
item.description: Carriageworks owes more than $2 million to 225 creditors, according to documents filed with ASIC.
item.title: Sydney's major arts companies caught up in Carriageworks collapse

item.dc:creator: Nick O'Malley
item.description: A new era of mega-fires has ravaged native forests so much that logging is now unsustainable, according to a study published in a leading science journal.
item.title: Logging in fire-ravaged native forests no longer sustainable: study

item.dc:creator: Simon Johanson
item.description: Thermal screening, temperature checks, lift queues and train carriage restrictions will confront workers as they emerge from home-based hibernation.
item.title: Drastic changes for CBD offices as workers gradually return

item.description: No Victorian government that acts according to the standards the community expects of it should have anything to fear from an estimates committee that is more robust.
item.title: Financial scrutiny more important than ever

item.dc:creator: David Crowe
item.description: As local councils call for urgent funding to boost the economy, the government is still to allocate more than $600m in funds promised at the election.
item.title: Federal government still to spend $600m promised to communities

item.dc:creator: David Crowe
item.description: Tourism groups have blasted the idea of waiting until September for Queensland to relax its border controls when coronavirus case numbers are falling.
item.title: 'Serves no purpose': Tourism industry warns of damage with closed state borders

item.dc:creator: Mary Ward
item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: As the day unfolded: COVID-19 inquiry gets international backing at World Health Assembly as Daniel Andrews spruiks $2.7b Victoria recovery package, nation's death toll at 99

item.dc:creator: Eryk Bagshaw
item.description: But China's President has stopped short of endorsing an independent probe advocated by Australia and the European Union.
item.title: Xi Jinping backs 'comprehensive review' of COVID-19

item.description: The seven-month-old boy was taken to Muswellbrook Hospital in an "unresponsive state" on Sunday afternoon, police said.
item.title: Police investigating 'suspicious' death of baby boy in NSW Hunter region

item.dc:creator: Marissa Calligeros
item.description: The number of confirmed coronavirus cases worldwide has almost reached 4.7 million.
item.title: As it happened: Premier announces $2.7 billion construction package, McDonald's shuts a dozen Victorian restaurants

item.description: The finest photos from the international wire agencies as chosen by our picture editors.
item.title: The best of the world in pictures

item.description: Masking up provides an instant invisible barrier.
item.title: Sleepless, stomping and Steel City
